content:
I just had this clash, and even with your coded solution, I don't get the point : for example, with first test, you have 2 players (4 and 2) : why/how can you have 3 words removed from original to remaining?
From results of my clash (2/8 had 100%, 6/8 0%), some explainations or step by step should be added here.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: 1) I would suggest naming test cases better (so people will get a hint of what pattern the test contains)
2) I would suggest having the number of players as a separate input.
E.g. not "4 2", but "2" and next line "4 2". In some languages, it's not easy to read until EOF.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Proper difficulty for a clash.

I like the idea!
It will be a very nice clash!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is definitely a fun clash, especially with how the telephone game can turn one piece of text into a completely different one. In terms of difficulty, I think this is perfect as I coded my solution in a few minutes, and this definitely seems like an original clash. 

Interpreting the problem is easy enough, so most of the focus in on the actual programming.

Nice clash indeed :-).
- What about adding, as edge case, one case with n=1 (and lifting '[[theRemainingPhrase]] always contains at least one word' from constraints to the statement as rule, i.e. it *should* always keep 1 word)? Kind of someone that only remembers the very last word that was said to him.
- And n=float for only remembering part of words :-) (no, don't do that please)

Anyway in its current state it is a nice clash - and possibly with one or two short [[theOriginalPhrase]] cases added it might serve as a very interesting reverse as well.

Nice clash!

Constraints section
* Suggest to mention that all [[n]]s are positive integers.

Stub generator
* Suggest to change "originalPhrase" to "theOriginalPhrase", and "Remaining Words" to "theRemainingPhrase" for consistency with other sections.

Thanks.

Thanks!!

Thanks for the feedback and I think I have made those changes now (perfect suggestions as always).

Please let me know if I need to change anything more or differently.
Thanks for the feedback.  Nice suggestion, but I've been told that I tend to propose clashes that are too much for a clash, so I'm just going to keep it simple :) and not add anything more.
Thank you soo much !!
Thank You !

Hey --
Thanks for commenting.  It's nice to hear feedback from actual players who play the clash.

So here is a step-by-step for the Test 1

The 1st kid to hear the message misses every 4th word.
So he hears:
The Bravo Remaining [[he misses Delta]] Echo Part.
In other words he hears:
The Bravo Remaining Echo Part.

The 2nd kid to hear that message misses every 2nd word.
So he hears:
The [[he misses Bravo]] Remaining [[he misses Echo]] Part.
In other words he hears:
The Remaining Part.

If you have a suggestion for any small change I could make, please tell me, but since it's been approved as is, I don't think I can/should make any big changes.

Would it help if I put "every" in bold ??
Thanks for the detail! Maybe you can say that each player can miss several words on each turn, what do you think? That's the point I didn't get in the clash
I made a change.  What do you think??
I think it will help understand the statement better!
Thanks again for the feedback ðŸ˜¸

Please state that n is an integer ("n > 1" implies n is positive but doesn't imply n is an integer).

And a remark: it's usually better not to show any reference links in clashes because players won't have much time to look things up during a clash, but it's also a balance between explanation and conciseness for a clash. In this case I guess it's also ok to have the link shown for those who really don't have any idea what the game is about.

Thanks again.

Okay I added a line in constraints, stating that.

My thought process is:
How could "n" be anything other than an int?!?  I explain that "n" is the position.  How could something be 7.8th in a list for example?  (Thats absurd on its face; It has to be an int.)

But I bow to your judgment about including this, since you are so experienced, and I suppose it is better to over-explain.

(Thanks again for your feedback; you are amazing how you take onboard everyone's attempted contributions and have great feedback on all the different types.)

I understand that n should not be an integer, and that's exactly what the constraints section is for. Alternatively, such a fact should be stated in the Input section for the player to understand what type of variables they are expected to parse.

There are other clashes where the author specifically throws in nonsense input data in some of the cases, and ask the players to output INVALID or something like that in those cases.

So, in short, stating the variable type is a good habit in the context of clashes and puzzles, to assure the players of what they should expect to parse and what cases they should expect to solve.

I fully understand that some will not agree with me on this point, and think I'm just making excessive requirements :P

I actually saw your remark in parenthesis last time, but I needed some time to think about how to reply to that properly. Hence the delay.

Sometimes the process of reviewing contributions can feel very exhausting and discouraging to me. I don't even know if I can go on like this for a long time.

But thanks to the nice words from you and some of the other players, I'm able to keep my spirit up at this task. The encouragement means a lot to me. Thank you very much!
